thread.title: ZINK: San Jacinto's Irving gets second chance at football with Cowboys
thread.title_full: ZINK: San Jacinto's Irving gets second chance at football with Cowboys - Press Enterprise

author: The Press-Enterprise
title: ZINK: San Jacinto's Irving gets second chance at football with Cowboys
text:
STAFF COLUMNIST
Published: Oct. 10, 2015 Updated: Oct. 11, 2015 9:51 a.m. As he hurriedly reached for products to fill pallet orders in Home Depotâs 600,000 square-foot Ontario distribution center, David Irving felt completely out of place, wondering how a seemingly menial task could be as grueling as his former job, playing defensive tackle at Iowa State University.
Irving, on his first day of a new job, dashed around the warehouse, wondering if heâd ever felt as exhausted in football practice as he did trying to keep up.
The 6-foot-7, 22-year-old from San Jacinto, who had been thrown out of school for two indiscretions eight months earlier, was being taken to school by a man twice his age.
Irving raced around the warehouse, stacking pallets with products, then going into the cold night to load them into trucks. Back and forth Irving went for 10 hours.
That night, Irving told himself heâd never settle for such a job, vowing to do whatever it took to get back into football.
Today, 10 months since that night in a warehouse, Irving is a member of the Dallas Cowboys, and one step from realizing the goal he envisioned for himself â" becoming a starting defensive lineman in the National Football League.
âHonestly, our (football) practices were hard but that one shift at Home Depot was probably the hardest thing Iâve ever done,â said Irving, who promptly got sick from the constant in and out, from hot to cold, then quit after two days in bed. âIt opened my eyes and showed me I have opportunities that not everyone else has.â
That night motivated Irving to call on an old friend and mentor to help him change the unfortunate, self-inflected circumstance of his life and lead him toward an opportunity to play in the National Football League.
Irving was determined to right the wrongs of his last year at Iowa State, where he was briefly suspended for a domestic disturbance, then was thrown out of school for a public disturbance in which he was involved.
But, the two incidents were too much for Iowa State coach Paul Rhoads to ignore. Irving was dismissed from Iowa State in April 2014.
That same day, Irving made the nearly 1,800-mile drive back to San Jacinto to live with his girlfriend, Angela Sanchez, and their daughter, Zoe, at Sanchezâs parentsâ house.
Awaiting him at San Jacinto High School was longtime coach Bill Powell, who coached Irving during his time in the Tigersâ program.
Luckily for Irving, Powell, who helped him get a scholarship to Iowa State through personal contacts, was still in Irvingâs corner, ready to help him get back on track with his life and football career.
âHe accepted accountability for his mistakes,â said Powell, who remained in close contact with Irving during his time in Ames. âI think that was the reality check he might have needed to kind of get him a little more focused on what he needed to do.â
MISSTEPS IN AMES
